company.name: EchoMetrix, Inc.
company.business_description: EchoMetrix develops and sells Sentry Parental Controls, a software program that monitors and records activity on target computers including web history, chat conversations, and instant message conversations. The company also operates The Pulse, a web-based market research software that aggregates and analyzes consumer opinion and sentiment from user-generated digital social media content.

case_info.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

complaint.factual_background: EchoMetrix, Inc. sold Sentry Parental Controls software to parents to monitor their children's online activity, including instant message conversations, websites visited, and applications used. In June 2009, EchoMetrix launched a separate web-based market research product called The Pulse, which aggregated consumer sentiment from online conversations. Without adequately disclosing this to Sentry purchasers, EchoMetrix fed data collected from children's online activity through the Sentry software into the Pulse database, which was then sold to third-party marketers and advertisers. The only potential notice given to Sentry purchasers was a vague statement buried approximately 30 paragraphs deep in a small scroll box EULA, which referred generically to 'anonymous reporting for internal and external clients' without identifying Pulse or the sharing of children's data with marketers.

representations_made.description: EchoMetrix represented that Sentry software would track all online activity on a computer, including instant message conversations, websites visited, and applications used by children — without disclosing that this collected data would be shared with third-party marketers through Pulse
representations_made.quoted_text: 1166.. counts.title: Deceptive Omission — Failure to Disclose Data Sharing with Third-Party Marketers
counts.representation: EchoMetrix represented, directly or indirectly, expressly or by implication, that Sentry software would track all online activity on a computer, including instant message conversations, websites visited, and applications used by children using the computer
counts.fact: EchoMetrix failed to adequately disclose that information revealed by children in connection with online activity monitored by Sentry would be disclosed to third-party marketers through Pulse; this material information was not adequately communicated to consumers and would have been material to their decision to purchase Sentry
counts.conclusion: The failure to adequately disclose the material information set forth in Paragraph 17, in light of the representation described in Paragraph 16, constitutes a deceptive act or practice in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

definitions.Defendant: EchoMetrix, Inc., and its successors and assigns.
definitions.Sentry: the Sentry Parental Controls software program, or any other similar software program marketed or sold by Defendant that can monitor and/or record activity on a computer.
definitions.Collected Information: any information or data collected by and transmitted from Sentry, from a computer on which Sentry is installed to any computer server owned by, operated by, or operated for the benefit of, Defendant.
definitions.Commerce: as defined in Section 4 of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 44.
definitions.Computer: any desktop or laptop computer, handheld device, telephone, or other electronic product or device that has a platform on which to download, install, or run any software program, code, script, or other content.
definitions.Personnel Necessary to Support Sentry: only those persons, whether employed by EchoMetrix or a third party, who require access to Collected Information to maintain the technical functioning of Sentry and who use the Collected Information solely for that purpose.
definitions.Registered Sentry User: a purchaser of Sentry, who is authorized (via login and password) to access Collected Information from a specific account or accounts.
definitions.Pulse: The Pulse service, or any substantially similar service marketed by Defendant that aggregates, collects, measures, or analyzes data from user-generated digital content (including but not limited to Internet forums, message boards, chats, blogs, and instant message conversations) for use by third parties.

provisions.title: Ban on Use of Information from Sentry
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from disclosing Collected Information to anyone other than Personnel Necessary to Support Sentry or a Registered Sentry User for the sole purpose of accessing that user's account.

requirements.description: Defendant and all persons in active concert with it are permanently enjoined and restrained from disclosing Collected Information to anyone other than Personnel Necessary to Support Sentry or a Registered Sentry User for the sole purpose of accessing that user's account.

provisions.title: Destruction of Collected Information
provisions.summary: Defendant must destroy, within 5 days of entry of the Order, any Collected Information transferred to or available in any database or server used by Pulse, except for information only available to Registered Sentry Users.

requirements.description: Defendant shall, no later than five (5) days after the date of entry of this Order, destroy any Collected Information that was transferred to or is available in any database or server used by Pulse, provided that Collected Information on a database or server only available to Registered Sentry Users need not be destroyed.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendant must notify the FTC of structural changes for 4 years, submit sworn annual compliance reports starting 60 days after entry, notify of bankruptcy within 15 days, and send all reports by overnight courier or first-class mail with simultaneous electronic copy.

requirements.description: For a period of four (4) years from the date of entry of this Order, Defendant shall notify the Commission of any changes in its structure or any business entity that Defendant directly or indirectly controls, or has an ownership interest in, that may affect compliance obligations, at least thirty (30) days prior to such change (or as soon as practicable if less than 30 days' notice is possible).

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC is authorized to monitor and investigate Defendant's compliance, including requiring written reports, document production, depositions, and facility access, as well as using discovery procedures and posing as consumers or suppliers.

requirements.description: Within ten (10) days of receipt of written notice from a Commission representative, Defendant shall submit additional written reports sworn under penalty of perjury, produce documents for inspection and copying, appear for deposition, and provide entry during normal business hours to any business location in Defendant's possession or control.

provisions.title: Record-Keeping Requirements
provisions.summary: Defendant must create and retain for seven years specific records related to Sentry and Pulse, including accounting records, personnel records, customer files, complaints, advertising materials, and all documents necessary to demonstrate full compliance with this Order.

requirements.description: For a period of seven (7) years from the date of entry of this Order, Defendant and its agents, employees, officers, corporations, and those in active concert or participation with them must create and retain accounting records reflecting revenues generated by sale of Sentry and Pulse and disbursement of such revenues.

requirements.description: Retain complaints and refund requests (whether received directly or indirectly, such as through a third party), including reports of disclosure of personal information claimed to be associated with the use of Sentry or Pulse, and any responses to those complaints or requests.

requirements.description: Retain all records and documents necessary to demonstrate full compliance with each provision of this Order, including copies of acknowledgments of receipt of this Order required by the 'Distribution of Order' and 'Acknowledgment of Receipt of Order' sections, and all reports submitted to the Commission pursuant to the 'Compliance Reporting' section.

provisions.title: Distribution of Order
provisions.summary: Defendant must deliver copies of the Order to principals, officers, directors, managers, relevant employees, agents, and successor business entities within specified timeframes, and must obtain signed acknowledgments of receipt within 30 days of delivery.

requirements.description: For a period of four (4) years from the date of entry of this Order, Defendant shall deliver a copy of this Order to: (1) all of its principals, officers, directors, and managers; (2) all of its employees, agents, and representatives who engage in conduct related to the subject matter of this Order; and (3) any business entity resulting from any change in structure set forth in Subsection A of the Compliance Reporting section. For current personnel, delivery shall be within five (5) days of service of this Order upon Defendant. For new personnel, delivery shall occur prior to their assuming their responsibilities. For any business entity resulting from a change in structure, delivery shall be at least ten (10) days prior to the change in structure.

requirements.deadline: 5 days for current personnel; prior to assuming responsibilities for new personnel; 10 days prior for successor entities

requirements.description: Defendant must secure a signed and dated statement acknowledging receipt of the Order, within thirty (30) days of delivery, from all persons receiving a copy of the Order pursuant to this section.

provisions.title: Acknowledgment of Receipt of Order
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit a truthful sworn statement to the FTC acknowledging receipt of this Order within five business days of receiving it.

requirements.description: Defendant, within five (5) business days of receipt of this Order as entered by the Court, shall submit to the Commission a truthful sworn statement acknowledging receipt of this Order.

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.

requirements.description: This Court shall retain jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.

duration.termination_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that this Court shall retain jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
